thread.title: Whole-team defence needed to nullify St Kilda’s master and apprentice, says Jackson Trengove | The
thread.title_full: Whole-team defence needed to nullify St Kilda’s master and apprentice, says Jackson Trengove | The Advertiser

author: RICHARD EARLE
title: Whole-team defence needed to nullify St Kilda’s master and apprentice, says Jackson Trengove | The
text:
FRUSTRATED president David Koch rates 2015 the year of Port Adelaide’s great “let-down” but key defender Jackson Trengove dismisses any assertion the Power players have got ‘ahead of themselves’.
Trengove - who, along with skipper Travis Boak is a true figure of influence and respect at Alberton - says its important to differentiate between internal and outside expectation.
Residing in 12th spot entering Round 17 isn’t where Port wanted to be, having set the grand final as a benchmark after a three-point preliminary final loss to Hawthorn last year.
“I wouldn’t say we are ahead of ourselves as a club; not everything has gone right as a footy club and we will be the first to put our hands up,” said Trengove, adding Port was set to “explode” in the race to September.
“The form has been an issue but we are doing a lot of work behind the scene to get ourselves back there. It has been a learning curve.”
The heat remains on Port Adelaide’s defence, which will again be without linchpin Alipate Carlile and possibly Jasper Pittard, who must prove he’s overcome an ankle strain.
St Kilda’s master Nick Riewoldt and apprentice Paddy McCartin - the No.1 draft pick of 2014 - will pose a hazard from 12.10pm Sunday at Adelaide Oval.
Riewoldt, 32, booted three goals in St Kilda’s comfortable win against Melbourne at the MCG last round and remains potent in the twilight of his glorious career, despite a nagging calf ailment.
“Nick Riewoldt has been a superstar of the game for a ridiculous amount of years and our back six will have our work cut out with their forwards,” said Trengove
It will take a tag-team effort to nullify triple All Australian Riewoldt.
“It’s a good challenge for us as a group. We have a younger group down back but it’s a chance for our team to defend as one,” said Trengove.
Port is two games behind eighth-placed North Melbourne and must win its remaining six games to slip into the finals.
Only an elusive four-quarter effort - that was the hallmark of its consecutive final appearances in 2013-14 - will cut it against Alan Richardson’s resurgent Saints.
“Every week now is a pressure game but we have a little bit of form back,” said Trengove of Port, which defeated Essendon by 13 points last Saturday at Etihad Stadium.
“I think we are building towards that four-quarter performance, team footy and keeping the opposition to a low score.
“You can’t get caught in your own game but we have to go back to that team-style defence of previous years.”
.
